text: A20 inhibits <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation

<extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling induces the activation of NF-kappaB , <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription factors , which promote the expression of proinflammatory cytokines and type I IFNs that restrict further viral propagation .

Previous studies have shown that ectopically expressed A20 negatively regulates NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation upon <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation [ 50 ] - [ 52 ] .

Similarly , we show that A20 overexpression in HEK293T cells prevents NF-kappaB - and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent <extra_id_0> luciferase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> reporter gene activation induced by transfection of a <extra_id_0> truncated constitutive active form <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> of <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 53 ] , corresponding to only the two N-terminal CARD domains of <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ RIG-I ( 2CARD ) ] ( figure 1A , left and middle graph ) .
We next investigated whether A20 also inhibits <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation .

Unlike <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is not or weakly expressed under naive conditions and <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein levels are rapidly upregulated upon virus - induced <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation [ 54 ] , [ 55 ] .

To determine the effect of A20 on <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , we therefore transfected minor amounts of an <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression plasmid together with plasmids encoding RIG-I ( 2CARD ) , A20 and an <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - specific IFNalpha4 <extra_id_0> luciferase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> reporter construct .

RIG-I ( 2CARD ) expression in the absence of <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> co-expression showed negligible IFNalpha4 promoter activation ( grey bar , figure 1A , right graph ) , whereas significant reporter gene expression was observed in the presence of <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Similar to its inhibitory effect on NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , A20 also prevented <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> IRF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation ( figure 1A , right graph ) .

These results demonstrate the potential of A20 to inhibit <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation .

To study the effect of endogenously expressed A20 on <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced signaling in a more immunological relevant context , we performed further experiments in A20 deficient primary macrophages .

Since A20 full knockout mice die prematurely as a result of severe multi-organ inflammation [ 37 ] , we generated mice carrying a conditional A20 allele in which exon IV and exon V were flanked by two loxP sites [ 56 ] .

Crossing these mice with transgenic mice expressing Cre recombinase under control of the lysozyme M promoter leads to specific deletion in myeloid cells and allowed us to generate myeloid cell specific A20 knockout mice [ 48 ] .

To stimulate the <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> receptor , we transfected A20myel-KO BMDM and wild type control cells with minimal amounts of low molecular weight ( LMW ) poly ( I : C ) , which is known to preferentially bind and activate <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> rather than <extra_id_0> MDA5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 57 ] .

Of note , this concentration of poly ( I : C ) was unable to induce significant <extra_id_0> TLR3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> dependent NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation or cytokine production ( data not shown ) .
As expected , poly ( I : C ) transfection induced the rapid expression of A20 in wild type , but not in A20myel-KO BMDM ( figure 1B , upper panel ) .
At early time points , slightly slower migrating forms of A20 were observed , indicating that A20 undergoes a yet unknown modification upon poly ( I : C ) transfection .

Compared to wild type BMBM , A20 deficient cells showed enhanced NF-kappaB activation as indicated by increased phosphorylation and sustained degradation of <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( figure 1B ) .

Furthermore , nuclear translocation of the <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> NF-kappaB subunit was enhanced in poly ( I : C ) transfected A20myel-KO BMDM , reaching a maximum at earlier time points compared to wild type cells ( figure 1C ) .

<extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is known to be activated upon phosphorylation of a series of carboxyl terminal serine residues by the IKK-like kinases <extra_id_0> TBK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IKKepsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 58 ] , leading to its dimerization and subsequent translocation to the nucleus [ 59 ] .

Using immunoblotting with an antibody directed against phosphorylated Ser396 , maximum <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation was detected at earlier time points in A20myel-KO BMDM compared to wild type BMDM ( figure 1B ) .

Similar to <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> nuclear translocation reached its maximum at an earlier time point in A20 deficient BMDM compared to wild type cells ( figure 1C ) .

NF-kappaB controls the expression of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> control the expression of <extra_id_0> IFNbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

In line with the enhanced activation of NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as described above , A20myel-KO BMDM secreted increased amounts of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IFNbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( figure 1D ) .
Similar results were obtained using peritoneal macrophages ( data not shown ) .

Together , these results demonstrate that A20 plays an important role in the negative regulation of <extra_id_0> RIG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappaB and <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation in primary macrophages .
